clean_story:
"Brain rewiring. Skills shape it. "

Neuroplasticity means your brain changes like clay—soft, moldable, reshaping with practice.


Most think talent is fixed.
But your brain rewires itself when you learn—like a forest growing new paths after each hike.

Every time you practice a guitar chord or juggle, neurons fire together.
Repetition strengthens those connections, making actions faster, smoother.

London taxi drivers, memorizing 25,000 streets, grow larger hippocampus regions—proof skills reshape hardware.

Even after injury, brains reroute. Stroke patients relearn speech by forcing new neural links, like detouring around a blocked road.

The rule? Use it or lose it.
Unused skills fade; practiced ones sharpen.

Three related subjects are muscle memory mechanics, sleep and skill retention, and aging brain flexibility.
